level.toc-caption: [22,300] The arbitration system generally

p.text: Legislation cited in [22,300] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 Pt 5, ss 38–55.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 20.8–20.12, r 42.12, Sch 1.

heading.title: The arbitration system generally

p.text: The relevant machinery provisions governing referrals to Arbitration may be found in:
r 42.12 (Costs in relation to rehearings);
Form 31 “Arbitrator award and Registrar Notice”;
Form 32 “Notice of Motion — Rehearing after Arbitration”
CPA Pt 5 does not apply in the Small Claims Division: Sch 1 , column 3.

These provisions together embody a scheme by which short and uncomplicated cases suitable for determination by informal arbitration may be removed from the ordinary court processes: Adair v Morahan (1986) 5 NSWLR 146 . From its inception, this system, which is distinct from that operating under the Commercial Arbitration Act 1984, has operated in all three tiers of the NSW hierarchy of courts, and has proved extremely successful in reducing arrears in all jurisdictions.

The following commentary is intended as an overview on aspects of the process only, and is not intended to be comprehensive. In some instances, the commentary supplements the footnotes to the Act and Rules. Where any doubt arises, the specific provisions of the Act and Rules should be consulted.

level.toc-caption: [22,305] The operation of the scheme (with particular reference to the Local Court)

p.text: Legislation cited in [22,305] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

heading.title: The operation of the scheme (with particular reference to the Local Court)

level.toc-caption: [22,305.5] Appointment of arbitrators

heading.title: Appointment of arbitrators

p.text: Under the scheme, the Chief Magistrate appoints “suitable persons” to be arbitrators to hear and determine actions referred to arbitration under s 38 of the CPA. A person may not be so appointed unless he is a barrister or solicitor nominated in the prescribed manner by his or her appropriate professional body: CPA s 36(2) .

As from 1 January 2002 arbitrators have been appointed on a two-year basis. Both the Law Society of New South Wales and the Bar Association have established selection committees which will invite applications every second year from their general membership and recommend suitable applicants for appointment. Applicants for appointment are required to satisfy selection criteria which include the following requirements:
the applicant shall be the holder of a current practising certificate and hold such certificate through the duration of the appointment;

the applicant shall be an accredited specialist, or be able to demonstrate that he or she has comparable experience and expertise, in the following fields of law relevant to the type of cases which the applicant would be required to arbitrate:
Motor Vehicle Accidents;
Building Work;
Commercial Law;
Consumer Law;
the applicant shall have substantial experience in the conduct of litigation in the Local Court. Although desirable, prior experience as an arbitrator shall not be essential.

The form of appointment is made for the Local Court generally and is not specific to particular Local Courts. While it is possible for cases to be referred to arbitrators not within the court's district, such referrals should not be made if there is a likelihood of inconvenience to the parties.
The document “Delegated Powers of Registrars” at [21,000] , contains provisions as to which registrars are entitled to refer a matter to arbitration, and otherwise deal with the matter, as follows:

level.toc-caption: [22,305.10] Types of action which may not be referred to arbitration

heading.title: Types of action which may not be referred to arbitration

p.text: Proceedings in which there is an allegation of fraud, or proceedings in the Small Claims Division may not be referred to arbitration “unless the parties consent or the court finds there are special circumstances to justify their referral”: r 20.8 . Where there is an allegation of fraud, and a party seeks a referral to arbitration, it is submitted that the best course is for the matter to be referred to a magistrate to determine whether there are special circumstances.

Despite r 20.8(b) , UCPR Sch 1 , column 3 states quite blandly that Pt 5 (which includes Div 2 — “Arbitration” does not apply to the Small Claims Division (at all). As to circumstances of a more general nature which may preclude a referral to arbitration, see CPA s 38(3) : no issue in the proceedings contested; rules of court to the contrary; cause otherwise shown).

The mode of referral to alternative dispute resolution, including mediation and arbitration, is prescribed by Practice Note Civ 1 of 2011, cl 9. Such a referral can be considered at the first or second callover, but not upon any further adjournment of the callover. “Proceedings will generally only be considered for arbitration if they are property damage claims arising out of motor vehicle accidents or other uncomplicated proceedings estimated to take 3 hours or less at hearing”: cl 9.6.

level.toc-caption: [22,305.15] Procedure to be determined by the arbitrator

heading.title: Procedure to be determined by the arbitrator

p.text: The procedure at an arbitration is to be determined by the arbitrator, who, subject to the rules of evidence, must act according to equity, good conscience and the substantial merits of the case without regard for technicalities of legal forms: CPA s 49 . These provisions highlight the informal procedural character of an arbitration, while at the same time obliging the arbitrator to comply with the rules of evidence, in attempting to achieve a resolution of disputed issues in a referred action. They may be compared and contrasted with the procedure in the Small Claims Division of the Court, where proceedings are required to be conducted with as little formality and technicality as the proper consideration of the matter permits, and where the rules of evidence do not apply: LCA 2007 s 39 . As to “equity and good conscience”, the test to be applied is to firstly ask what is the strict legal situation, and then to ask whether the concepts of equity and good conscience demand some variation from the application of strict legal principles: Complete Windscreen Service Nominees Pty Ltd v Cora Nominees Pty Ltd (SC(SA), Mulligan J, S4020, 1 July 1993, unreported, BC9300319); see also HG Collett Pty Ltd v Alsop (1982) 49 SAIR 309 . Other authorities are noted at [s 49.5] .

level.toc-caption: [22,305.20] Arbitrator's duty to attempt conciliation

heading.title: Arbitrator's duty to attempt conciliation

p.text: There does not appear to any duty imposed upon the arbitrator to conciliate before making an award, as there was under the former legislation.

level.toc-caption: [22,305.25] The taking of evidence before the arbitrator

heading.title: The taking of evidence before the arbitrator

p.text: Evidence is given and received by an arbitrator “in the same way as it would be given and received before the referring court”, save that there is no obligation to have the proceedings recorded. “An arbitrator may administer an oath, or take an affidavit for the purpose of proceedings of the referred proceedings”: CPA s 51 . As to perjury, and the arbitrator's options where a witness refuses or fails to take an oath, see CPA ss 51(4) and 52 respectively. As to recording, see [s 51.5] .

level.toc-caption: [22,305.30] Jurisdiction

heading.title: Jurisdiction

p.text: The jurisdiction conferred on the arbitrator in relation to a referred proceedings is “part of the jurisdiction of the court by which the proceedings were referred”, and “an arbitrator has and may exercise, in relation to referred proceedings, all of the powers and authorities of the court by which the action was referred”: CPA s 37(1), (2) .

This section presumably confers upon the arbitrator the powers and authorities conferred upon the court under the Rules in relation to such matters as the amendment of pleadings and addition of parties. Whether an arbitrator should in fact exercise such powers is a question of fact and degree to be determined in all the circumstances of the action. For example, an amendment authorising the addition of a party prima facie widens the scope of the action referred for arbitration, and may thus be perceived as being beyond the arbitrator's power, the arbitrator's jurisdiction being limited to hearing and determining the referred proceedings. It is submitted that once an action has been referred to arbitration, the addition of a party is such a radical step, necessarily widening the scope of the referred proceedings, that it should be refused. Alternatively, the matter should be referred back to the court under r 20.9 .

However, circumstances may arise where the addition of a party may be achieved simply and without necessarily extending the hearing time or enlarging the issues for determination, even though a widening of the scope of the referred proceedings may be achieved in the process. For example, in referred proceedings in which A as plaintiff claims damages for negligence against B following a motor vehicle accident, the addition of an additional plaintiff C, who had property in A's car which was also damaged in the accident, would be unlikely to lengthen the hearing time or widen the issues for determination at all, assuming that there is no dispute about C's ownership of the property or as to quantum. Instances have arisen where arbitrators have acceded to applications for the addition of a party in these circumstances. Each such application should be considered in its own circumstances in the context that the arbitrator's jurisdiction is to hear and determine the “referred proceedings”.

Similar considerations apply as regards the amendment of pleadings. Most such applications are capable of being dealt with simply and expeditiously, applying the usual considerations governing amendments in civil matters, namely, is there any prejudice to the other side, and if so, is such prejudice capable of being remedied by an appropriate order for costs and the imposition of other orders or terms. Circumstances may arise where the addition of a cross-claim after referral will considerably widen the scope of the referred proceedings, particularly if the cross-claim sought to be added raises new causes of action or issues in the proceedings. If so, it is submitted that the arbitrator should not accede to the amendment and either proceed to hear and determine the matter as referred, or depending on the circumstances, refer the matter back to the court under r 20.9 . The merits of the application may then be considered by the court. By way of analogy, in Commonwealth v Cockatoo Dockyard Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Rolfe J, No 50250/94, 3 November 1994, unreported, BC94051142) a decision under the Commercial Arbitration Act 1984, which provides a code for commercial arbitrations and is therefore distinct from arbitrations under the CP Act , the Arbitrator allowed the plaintiff (inter alia) to amend its claim in order to widen its claim for loss of profits. It was held that there was no jurisdictional basis for interfering with an arbitrator's decision in a matter of practice and procedure where there had been no breach of the rules of natural justice or other technical misconduct.

level.toc-caption: [22,305.35] No date endorsed on the award

heading.title: No date endorsed on the award

p.text: Should a date fail to be endorsed on the award, the period of 28 days does not commence to run. Consequently the award will not be deemed to be a judgment of the court until a date is endorsed on a copy of the award forwarded to each party: Solomon v Design Resource International Pty Ltd (NSWLC, Lawson M, No 7855/89, unreported). The New South Wales Court of Appeal came to the same conclusion as regards the identical provisions of the now repealed 1973 District Court Act and Rules in Walshe v Prest [2004] NSWCA 94; BC200401451 .

level.toc-caption: [22,305.40] Arbitrator’s decision may be challenged if jurisdiction lacking or denial of natural justice

heading.title: Arbitrator’s decision may be challenged if jurisdiction lacking or denial of natural justice

p.text: On transmitting the award to the Local Court an arbitrator is functus officio. CPA s 40 , by which an arbitrator's award is expressed to be final and conclusive, is inconsistent with the existence of a right of appeal, and effective to exclude the Supreme Court's general jurisdiction to supervise inferior tribunals: see generally Adair v Morahan (1986) 5 NSWLR 146 per Kearney J.

The ouster of any form of judicial review of an arbitrator's decision under CPA s 41 (excepting an aggrieved person's right to apply for a rehearing under Pt 3), does not apply where the relief or remedy is sought on the ground of a lack of jurisdiction or a denial of natural justice: s 41(2) . “Implicit in the concept of (natural justice or) fair adjudication lie two cardinal principles, namely, that no man shall be a judge in his own cause (nemo judex in causa sua), and that no man shall be condemned unheard (audi alteram partem)”: Halsbury's Laws of England , 4th ed, Reissue, Butterworths, Vol 1(1), para 84 p 157, 1989. It has been said that it is also a breach of the rules of natural justice for a tribunal to act upon evidence which has no probative value: R v Deputy Industrial Injuries Cmr; Ex parte Moore [1965] 1 QB 456 at 476, 488; [1965] 1 All ER 81 at 87, 94 . See also Boyd v Carroll (NSWSC, Clarke J, No 14269/85, 21 October 1985, unreported, BC8500466). It is also considered a tenet of natural justice that a court or other tribunal exercising judicial power has a duty to act fairly and to give the parties reasonable notice of the hearing: Brack v Wills [1977] 1 NSWLR 456 ; Hoggard v Worsborough Urban District Council [1962] 2 QB 93 ; Delta Properties Pty Ltd v Brisbane City Council (1955) 95 CLR 11; [1955] ALR 869; BC5500420 ; Police v Tanos (1958) 98 CLR 383 . For a discussion of the general principles relating to natural justice and its denial, see Halsbury's Laws of England , above, Vol 1(1), pp 157–94.

level.toc-caption: [22,310] Applications for rehearing

p.text: Legislation cited in [22,310] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 20.12(1), r 36.15, r 42.12.

heading.title: Applications for rehearing

level.toc-caption: [22,310.5] Transitional provisions governing applications for rehearing following increase in prescribed amount

heading.title: Transitional provisions governing applications for rehearing following increase in prescribed amount

p.text: In Csalar v Circosta (2002) 55 NSWLR 212; [2002] NSWSC 482; BC200202888 , O'Keefe J held that when the prescribed amount is increased, whether an application for a rehearing may be made is governed by the jurisdictional limit at the date the application for rehearing is made, and not the date upon which the proceedings were commenced. (Statement of claim filed on 1 November 1999 when the jurisdictional limit for seeking a rehearing was $3000; referral to arbitration on 1 July 2000; jurisdictional limit increased from $3000 to $10,000 on 25 September 2000; award on 13 November 2000; application for rehearing on 4 December 2000). O'Keefe J held that no application for rehearing could be made since the jurisdictional limit at the time the application for rehearing was made was $10,000. However, his Honour was not referred to Sch 12 of the Courts Legislation Amendment Act 2000 which inserted a new Pt 6 into Sch 2 of the Local Courts (Civil Claims) Act 1970 (now repealed) stating: “The amendments made to section 12 of the Act by the Courts Legislation Amendment Act 1999 do not apply in respect of proceedings commenced before those amendments”. An explanatory note says that this provision “makes it clear that the increase (from $3000 to $10,000) in the jurisdiction of the Small Claims Division of the Local Court (as made by the Courts Legislation Amendment Act 1999) does not apply in relation to proceedings commenced before the relevant amendment”. In Dear v Cassar (Local Court, Downing Centre, Cloran M, No 10491/02, 4 December 2002, unreported ), Magistrate Cloran (as he then was) was faced with a similar factual situation. While pointing out that O'Keefe J was not referred to Sch 12 of the Courts Legislation Amendment Act 2000, he felt obliged to follow O'Keefe J's decision on the basis of the doctrine of stare decisis. Had he not been obliged to follow O'Keefe J's decision, Magistrate Cloran would have held that the arbitration determination was validly the subject of an application for rehearing. Magistrate Lulham came to the opposite conclusion, holding that the principles of stare decisis did not apply to O'Keefe J's decision, in Fuller v Murphy (Local Court, Downing Centre, Lulham M, No 153767/00, 12 December 2003, unreported). Both decisions are reproduced behind the guide card "Practice Decisions" at [456,115] , [456,130] .

level.toc-caption: [22,310.10] No time limit prescribed for application for rehearing in s 42

heading.title: No time limit prescribed for application for rehearing in s 42

p.text: An application for rehearing is made by motion: r 20.12(1) . No time limit is specified in either CPA ss 42 or 43 . As to the significance of this, and whether the court still has a discretion to order a rehearing after the award has become a judgment, see [s 42.15]. The court may order a full hearing or a limited rehearing.

level.toc-caption: [22,310.15] Proceedings to be heard as if never referred to arbitration: s 44(1)

heading.title: Proceedings to be heard as if never referred to arbitration: s 44(1)

p.text: If an order is made for full rehearing, then the award ceases to have effect, and the action is heard and determined by the court as if it had never been referred to an arbitrator: CPA s 44(1) . If the order is for a limited rehearing, under s 44(2) the arbitrator's award is only suspended, and the aspects ordered to be dealt with at the limited rehearing are heard and determined by the court as if they had not been dealt with in the arbitration. After a limited rehearing, the court may then reinstate the award with such modifications (if any) as the court thinks appropriate. The award, as reinstated, is final and conclusive, and is taken to be a judgment of the court.

There were once two views as to the effect of s 44(1) . One view was that any evidence in relation to what occurred or what the parties said at the arbitration is inadmissible. However, s 44(1) does not use those words and the Parliament could have used them had it desired to achieve this effect. Instead it used the more elliptical “shall be heard and determined ... as if they had never been referred to an arbitrator”. The other view was that the subsection is merely intended to reinforce the nature of the rehearing before the court as a hearing de novo, entirely independent of the earlier proceedings, and that s 44(1) does not operate to oust the law relating to the admissibility of prior inconsistent statements. Therefore a witness may be asked whether he or she made a prior statement before the arbitrator which was inconsistent with the testimony now being given. For example, the witness may readily admit the inconsistency and may seek to explain it, in which case it would be illogical that evidence of the inconsistency could not be given.

This debate has now been settled by the decision of Finlay J in Najdanovic v Brown (t/as Taylor's A1 Transport Co) (NSWSC, CLD 15136/82, Finlay J, 22 September 1992, unreported, BC9203158), to the effect that the words “shall be heard and determined in the court as if it had never been referred to an arbitrator” preclude either party using any of the material, including the transcript of evidence, before the arbitrator (unless, of course, by consent to facilitate the hearing). See also Courtenay v Proprietors Strata Plan No 12125 (NSWCA, Priestley, Sheller, Beazley JJA, CA 40599/96, 30 October 1998, unreported, BC9807357), where it was held that upon a re-hearing a witness may not be asked questions concerning the evidence given at arbitration because the Act provides that the re-hearing is to take place as though the arbitration had never occurred.

level.toc-caption: [22,310.20] Discontinuance of rehearing: s 45

heading.title: Discontinuance of rehearing: s 45

p.text: A rehearing may be discontinued, but only with the consent of all parties or by leave of the court: CPA s 45(1) . The court is then obliged to reinstate the award which becomes final and conclusive, is taken to be a judgment of the referring court, and, unless the court otherwise orders, is taken to have had effect under s 40(b) had no application for rehearing been made. The court may award costs in relation to discontinued proceedings: CPA s 46(3) .

level.toc-caption: [22,310.25] Costs of rehearing: s 46 and r 42.12

heading.title: Costs of rehearing: s 46 and r 42.12

p.text: Costs on rehearing are provided for in r 42.12 . The rule is intended to discourage ill-considered applications for rehearing. Unless the court's determination is “substantially more favourable” to the party who requested the rehearing than was the determination of the arbitrator, then, unless there are special circumstances, the court shall not make an order for the payment of the applicant's costs of the rehearing, but shall order that party to pay the costs of any other party incurred by reason of the rehearing.. What is a determination “substantially more favourable” to the applicant's position is a question of fact to be determined in all the circumstances of the case. Conceivably, a party may better his or her position, for example, by having an assessment of that party's own contributory negligence reduced or even expunged, yet the overall result may not be considered substantially more favourable than the position enjoyed under the arbitrator's award with the result that unless there are special circumstances, he or she will still be ordered to pay the costs of every other party occasioned by the rehearing.

level.toc-caption: [22,310.30] Costs of the arbitration where the arbitration is used as a “dry run”

heading.title: Costs of the arbitration where the arbitration is used as a “dry run”

p.text: The court that hears and determines a rehearing of referred proceedings may, in addition to making an appropriate order for the costs of the rehearing , make a like order for the payment of costs in respect of the hearing before the arbitrator: : CPA s 46(1)(b), 46(2)(b) . In MacDougall v Curlevski (1996) 40 NSWLR 430; BC9605362 , the defendants did not call evidence before the arbitrator and the arbitration was determined in favour of the plaintiff. On the rehearing, the defendants called evidence, resulting in a verdict in their favour. The trial judge awarded indemnity costs against the defendants as from and including the arbitration, an exercise of discretion which was not disturbed on appeal. Priestley AP observed at 434:

“[I]n my opinion, the court considering the costs questions is entitled to take into account, in deciding what the consequences of such a course should be, the desirability of actions referred to arbitrators for determination being determined once and for all by the arbitrator. The whole scheme of referred actions in the District Court [and indeed the Local Court] is aimed at speedier and cheaper decision of disputes, which by definition of the conditions subject to which actions may be referred to arbitration, are suitable for such decision. The scheme is not one designed to provide successive hearings by arbitrator and judge as a regular matter in which the first trial is to be regarded as a practice run, but rather one where the first trial is intended to be the final trial, subject to the re-hearing safeguard in the occasional, out of the ordinary, case. It seems to me, therefore, quite legitimate for courts in making costs orders, to promote, in appropriate cases, the use of the referred action system in what in my opinion is the intended way.”
Other instances:

In Quach v Mustafa (NSWCA, Kirby P, Sheller and Powell JJA, No 40106/95, 15 June 1995, unreported, BC9504778), at the arbitration the defendants did not produce evidence of video films which they had obtained of the plaintiff and which contradicted her account of the seriousness of her injuries. Instead, they produced them at the rehearing. Although the ultimate verdict the plaintiff obtained at the rehearing was less than the original offer of settlement, the trial judge ordered the defendants to pay the plaintiff's costs. In view of the “litigious charade” indulged in by the defendants before the arbitrator, the Court of Appeal did not disturb the costs order. This was so, notwithstanding that the defendants did not wish to show their hand at the arbitration in case the plaintiff tailored her evidence at the rehearing.

Following Quach, Solomon DCJ had made a similar order ordering the defendant to pay costs in Green v Lovatt (NSWDC, Solomon DCJ, 4 March 1997, unreported). Here it was the plaintiff who had applied for the rehearing, as opposed to the defendant in Quach. It was held on appeal (reported as Morgan v Johnson (1998) 44 NSWLR 578; BC9804556 ) that it was the plaintiff who had chanced his arm in the litigation. The defendant was ordered to pay the plaintiff's costs of the proceedings, including the costs of the arbitration, but each party was ordered to bear his or her own costs incurred by reason of the rehearing following the arbitration: Green v Lovatt (1998) 44 NSWLR 578 ; [1998] NSWSC 367; BC9804556 .

In Gambrill v Cook (1998) 44 NSWLR 578 ; [1998] NSWSC 367; BC9804556 the defendant had called four witnesses who had not been called at the arbitration. The plaintiff recovered a verdict for less than the sum offered. Since both parties knew of the evidence not called at the arbitration and then subsequently called at the rehearing, it was held on appeal that the plaintiff had no justification for rejecting the settlement offer and Pt 39A r 25(6) of the then District Court Rules should not have been displaced. For an instance of a costs order where the defendant requested a rehearing following an arbitration, comprehensively lost before the District Court, and had the judgment reduced on appeal to the Court of Appeal, the final judgment being more than the arbitrator's award but less than the defendant's offer of compromise, see Lee v Abbes [2003] NSWCA 24; BC200300429 .

In Howard v Telstra Corp Ltd [2003] NSWCA 188; BC200303887 the appellant only called himself as a witness in the arbitration and lost the action, because there was no corroboration. He called additional witnesses on the rehearing in the District Court and was successful. The trial judge ordered the defendant to pay the costs of the appellant up to and including the day before the arbitration, but that thereafter the appellant was to pay the costs of the defendant, including the costs of the arbitration. It was held that the trial judge had misapplied MacDougall v Curlevski (1996) 40 NSWLR 430; BC9605362 (where a deliberate decision was made not to call a witness at the arbitration for forensic reasons) and Morgan v Johnson, above, (where, unlike the present case, there was the additional element of a settlement offer made by the defendant and rejected by the plaintiff), and that the effect of the order was to deprive the appellant, a successful plaintiff, of the costs of any hearing of his action, indeed to make him pay the costs of both the arbitration and the trial. On appeal, the appellant was ordered to pay the costs of the arbitration and the defendant to pay the costs otherwise incurred in the proceedings below.

level.toc-caption: [22,310.35] Application to set aside a deemed judgment

heading.title: Application to set aside a deemed judgment

p.text: In Adair v Morahan (1986) 5 NSWLR 146 , Kearney J expressed the view that the words of the section expressed a clear legislative intent that there should be no judicial review available in respect of a decision made under the arbitration process. However, in Majetic v Brough (1986) 5 NSWLR 393 , Yeldham J held that the words of the section relate to the arbitrator's award and not to the judgment which is deemed to be entered up pursuant to the award, and accordingly, what is now s 40 did not operate to preclude an application to set aside a judgment entered up following an arbitrator's award. Kearney J's decision is generally conceded to be the better view on the subject. Nevertheless, Majetic v Brough, above , remains authority for the proposition that the court has the power to set aside a judgment entered following an arbitrator's award. However, the onus to be discharged by a party seeking to do so is now considerable, in that under r 36.15 the obligation is the show that “the judgment was given or entered, or the order was made, irregularly, illegally or against good faith.”

level.toc-caption: [22,315] Abuses of the arbitration system

heading.title: Abuses of the arbitration system

level.toc-caption: [22,315.5] Referral of lengthy, complex matters to arbitration

heading.title: Referral of lengthy, complex matters to arbitration

p.text: Over the years, many matters have been referred to arbitration which should never have been referred there in the first place, in view of the legislature's intent to establish a scheme whereby short and uncomplicated cases suitable for determination by informal arbitration may be removed from the ordinary court processes. Wildly inaccurate and ill-considered time estimates have been furnished to the registrar or court, and lack of proper consideration of the nature of the issues to be determined have resulted in matters of undue length and complexity being referred to arbitration. This can result in some matters lasting for days, rather than less than a day which is the ideal, with a consequent drain on the arbitration budget.

By virtue of Practice Note 1 of 2005, para 8.6.1, proceedings will generally only be considered for arbitration if they are property damage claims arising out of motor vehicle accidents or other uncomplicated proceedings estimated to take 3 hours or less at hearing. Arbitrators who receive matters by way of referral which clearly should never have been referred to arbitration in the first place, by virtue of the complexity of the issues or the anticipated length of hearing, should seek a revocation of the order for referral after discussion with the parties and the registrar of the referring court. Even if these factors only become apparent after the hearing has commenced consideration should still be given to seeking a revocation of the referral. Prolonged hearings present an unnecessary strain upon the arbitration budget for which it was never designed or intended.

level.toc-caption: [22,315.10] Using the arbitration as a “dry run”

heading.title: Using the arbitration as a “dry run”

p.text: In some cases, parties have been known to use the arbitration proceedings as a “dry run”, saving their real case for the trial. This contradicts the intention and spirit of the legislation which is intended to reduce costs and delay. The adoption of such a course, involving for example the calling of no evidence on damages before the arbitrator, may sound in a costs sanction as regards the costs lost or thrown when this issue is determined at the rehearing. The relevant principles are set out above at [22,310.30] .

However, there is nothing which prevents such a course from being adopted. “There is no provision or practice, so far as I am aware, that can, as a matter of law , preclude a party from deciding what evidence that party will call in a District Court [or, semble, a Local Court] action referred to an arbitrator”: MacDougall v Curlevski (1996) 40 NSWLR 430; BC9605362 (NSWLR) at 433 per Priestley AP (see also at 438 per Cole JA;); Central Sydney Area Health Service v Cooper [2001] NSWCA 329; BC200105631 at [16] per Sheller JA.

Nevertheless, the adoption of such a practice may properly be categorised as an abuse, as the remarks of Priestley AP in MacDougall, above as cited at [22,310.30] make clear. If the court is satisfied that such a course has been followed, an adverse order as to costs against the recalcitrant party may be expected to follow.

Further judicial disapproval of the practice of not calling all one's available evidence at the arbitration may be found in Howard v Telstra Corp Ltd [2003] NSWCA 188; BC200303887 , where Young CJ in Eq (Santow JA agreeing) said that:

“there is no excuse for any lawyer representing a party not to place before the arbitrator or judge all the evidence that needs to be called in order, forensically, to obtain a verdict [that] if those in practice do not see arbitrations at present, as being the final hearing, they should be treated as such in the future [and that] there is a principle that parties must put their best foot forward in District Court arbitrations and that cost penalties may be suffered if they do not. However, in the end result, the order for costs must be fair and just in all the circumstances of each particular case”.
It is submitted that such remarks are equally pertinent as regards Local Court arbitrations.

level.toc-caption: [22,330] Remuneration of arbitrators

p.text: Legislation cited in [22,330] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Arbitration (Civil Actions) Act 1983 s 5(8).

heading.title: Remuneration of arbitrators

p.text: IN pursuance of section 5(8) of the Arbitration (Civil Actions) Act 1983, I have made the following Determination for the remuneration of arbitrators. This Determination replaces the Determination of 25 February 1998:

1. Where an arbitrator is rostered to arbitrate in respect of proceedings in the District Court or the Local Court referred to arbitration on a day (known as Philadelphia arbitration) and attends the Court and conducts arbitrations and makes awards, the arbitrator shall be paid $702 for that day.

2. Where an arbitrator is rostered to arbitrate in respect of proceedings in the Supreme Court referred to arbitration on a day (known as Philadelphia arbitration) and attends the Court and conducts arbitrations and makes awards, the arbitrator shall be paid $820 for that day.

3. Where an arbitrator is rostered to arbitrate and conducts Philadelphia arbitrations for less than five hours and there are further matters available for allocation to the arbitrator which the arbitrator declines to conduct on the day the arbitrator's payment shall be reduced as determined by the Registrar.

4. If, in order to complete a matter it is necessary for an arbitrator to sit beyond 4.30 pm, then the arbitrator shall be paid $761 for Local or District Court matters for that day and $868 for Supreme Court matters for that day, provided that all matters called on for arbitration for that day are completed.

5. Where it is necessary to reserve any judgments on a Philadelphia arbitration day a total fee of $102 for Local and District Court matters and $113 for Supreme Court matters, shall be payable for completion of all reserved awards.

6. Where an arbitrator is allocated to a Philadelphia hearing outside the Sydney metropolitan area on an arbitration day the arbitrator shall be paid $809 and will be reimbursed for the actual cost of travelling and accommodation and paid a daily allowance. Accommodation will be payable to the limit of $96 per night and the daily allowance will be $64 per day. These rates shall not apply to hearings in Newcastle, Wollongong, Gosford, Penrith, Campbelltown or Liverpool and arbitrations allocated by Courts in these locations shall be payable in accordance with the other paragraphs of this Determination.

7. This Detemination shall be reviewable annually each July commencing in July 1998 on the basis of the annual escalation factor applied by the NSW Treasury to the Attorney General's Department budget allocation.

8. Where an arbitrator has been referred a matter for an arbitration hearing in the arbitrator's rooms (known as general arbitration) by the District Court or the Local Court the arbitrator shall be paid $161 for the first hour of hearing and $96 for every hour spent in hearing the action, or in attempting conciliation and $102 for an award.
9. Where a general arbitration matter is allocated to an arbitrator and the matter settles after the arbitrator has set the matter for a hearing date the arbitrator shall be paid $107.
10. Where the order referring a matter to arbitration is revoked the arbitrator shall be paid an amount, if any, as the Court revoking the order may direct, not exceeding $107.

11. The Registrar may increase the fees by 10% of the amount payable in respect of the service provided by the arbitrator, or the amount permitted by the New Tax System Price Exploitation Law, whichever is less.
12. For the purpose of this Determination the term "Registrar" shall include an officer to whom the Registrar's powers may be delegated.
Date: 26 June 2000

level.toc-caption: [22,330.5] Arbitrator’s remuneration

heading.title: Arbitrator’s remuneration

p.text: Section 36(6) of the Civil Procedure Act 2005, provides that “An arbitrator is entitled to such remuneration as the Minister may from time to time determine”. Although the above determination of 26 June 2000 was made pursuant to an Act now repealed, the Arbitration (Civil Actions) Act 1983, it remains the last and current determination dealing with the subject of arbitrator’s remuneration and arbitrators are still being paid pursuant to it.
Notified in Gaz 81 of 30 June 2000, p 5897.
